member.name: T:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase
member.summary: Represents the base class for action adapters.
member.remarks: This base class acts as a measurement concentrator which time aligns all incoming measurements for proper processing. Derived classes are expected to override to handle time aligned measurements and call for any new measurements that may get created.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.ConnectionString
member.summary: Gets or sets key/value pair connection information specific to action adapter.

remarks.para: Note that framesPerSecond, lagTime and leadTime are required parameters, all other parameters are optional.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.DataSource
member.summary: Gets or sets based data source available to this .

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.InitializationTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets maximum time system will wait during for initialization.
member.remarks: Set to to wait indefinitely.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.AutoStart
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if adapter should automatically start or otherwise connect on demand.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.RespectInputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on input demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start input demands, as an example, this would be false for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but true for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.RespectOutputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on output demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start output demands, as an example, this would be true for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but false for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.FramesPerSecond
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of frames per second.
member.remarks: Valid frame rates for a are greater than 0 frames per second.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.LagTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed past time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be sub-second).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to past measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too old.
This becomes the amount of delay introduced by the concentrator to allow time for data to flow into the system.

member.exception: LagTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.LeadTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed future time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be sub-second).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to future measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too advanced.
This becomes the tolerated +/- accuracy of the local clock to real-time.

member.exception: LeadTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.InputMeasurementKeys
member.summary: Gets or sets primary keys of input measurements the action adapter expects.
member.remarks: If your adapter needs to receive all measurements, you must explicitly set InputMeasurementKeys to null.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.OutputMeasurements
member.summary: Gets or sets output measurements that the action adapter will produce, if any.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.InputSourceIDs
member.summary: Gets or sets values used to filter input measurement keys.
member.remarks: This allows an adapter to associate itself with entire collections of measurements based on the source of the measurement keys. Set to null apply no filter.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.OutputSourceIDs
member.summary: Gets or sets values used to filter output measurements.
member.remarks: This allows an adapter to associate itself with entire collections of measurements based on the source of the measurement keys. Set to null apply no filter.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.RequestedInputMeasurementKeys

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.SetTemporalConstraint(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Defines a temporal processing constraint for the adapter.
member.param: Defines a relative or exact start time for the temporal constraint.
Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint.

remarks.para: This method defines a temporal processing constraint for an adapter, i.e., the start and stop time over which an adapter will process data. Actual implementation of the constraint will be adapter specific. Implementations should be able to dynamically handle multiple calls to this function with new constraints. Passing in null for the and should cancel the temporal constraint and return the adapter to standard / real-time operation.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

member.summary: Attempts to retrieve the minimum needed number of measurements from the frame (as specified by MinimumMeasurementsToUse)
member.param: Source frame for the measurements
Return array of measurements
member.returns: True if minimum needed number of measurements were returned in measurement array

remarks.para: Remember this function will *only* return the minimum needed number of measurements, no more. If you want to use all available measurements in your adapter you should just use Frame.Measurements.Values directly.
Note that the measurements array parameter will be created if the reference is null, otherwise if caller creates array it must be sized to MinimumMeasurementsToUse

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterCollection.RespectInputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on input demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start input demands, as an example, this would be false for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but true for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.ActionAdapterCollection.RespectOutputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on output demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start output demands, as an example, this would be true for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but false for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.AdapterBase.ConnectionString
member.summary: Gets or sets key/value pair connection information specific to this .

remarks.para:
Example connection string using measurements defined in a table:
inputMeasurementKeys={FILTER ActiveMeasurements WHERE Company='GSF' AND SignalType='FREQ' ORDER BY ID};
outputMeasurements={FILTER ActiveMeasurements WHERE SignalType IN ('IPHA','VPHA') AND Phase='+'}
Basic filtering syntax is as follows:
{FILTER <TableName> WHERE <Expression> [ORDER BY <SortField>]}
Source tables are expected to have at least the following fields:
Name Type Description.
ID NVARCHAR Measurement key formatted as: ArchiveSource:PointID.
PointTag NVARCHAR Point tag of measurement.
Adder FLOAT Adder to apply to value, if any (default to 0.0).
Multiplier FLOAT Multiplier to apply to value, if any (default to 1.0).

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.AdapterCollectionBase`1.SetTemporalConstraint(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Defines a temporal processing constraint for the adapter collection and applies this constraint to each adapter.
member.param: Defines a relative or exact start time for the temporal constraint.
Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint.

remarks.para: This method defines a temporal processing constraint for an adapter, i.e., the start and stop time over which an adapter will process data. Actual implementation of the constraint will be adapter specific. Implementations should be able to dynamically handle multiple calls to this function with new constraints. Passing in null for the and should cancel the temporal constraint and return the adapter to standard / real-time operation.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

member.summary: Represents the base class for simple, non-time-aligned, action adapters.
member.remarks: This base class acts on incoming measurements, in a non-time-aligned fashion, for general processing. If derived class needs time-aligned data for processing, the class should be used instead. Derived classes are expected call for any new measurements that may get created.

member.summary: Gets or sets output measurement keys that are requested by other adapters based on what adapter says it can provide.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.RespectInputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on input demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start input demands, as an example, this would be false for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but true for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.RespectOutputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on output demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start output demands, as an example, this would be true for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but false for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.FramesPerSecond
member.summary: Gets or sets the frames per second to be used by the .
member.remarks: This value is only tracked in the , derived class will determine its use.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.LagTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed past time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be sub-second).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to past measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too old.
This becomes the amount of delay introduced by the concentrator to allow time for data to flow into the system.

member.exception: LagTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.LeadTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed future time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be sub-second).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to future measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too advanced.
This becomes the tolerated +/- accuracy of the local clock to real-time.

member.exception: LeadTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.TrackLatestMeasurements
member.summary: Gets or sets flag to start tracking the absolute latest received measurement values.
member.remarks: Latest received measurement value will be available via the property.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.LatestMeasurements
member.summary: Gets reference to the collection of absolute latest received measurement values.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.UseLocalClockAsRealTime
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines whether or not to use the local clock time as real time.
member.remarks: Use your local system clock as real time only if the time is locally GPS-synchronized, or if the measurement values being sorted were not measured relative to a GPS-synchronized clock. Turn this off if the class is intended to process historical data.

member.summary: Gets the the most accurate time value that is available. If = true, then this function will return . Otherwise, this function will return the timestamp of the most recent measurement.

Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint.

remarks.para: This method defines a temporal processing constraint for an adapter, i.e., the start and stop time over which an adapter will process data. Actual implementation of the constraint will be adapter specific. Implementations should be able to dynamically handle multiple calls to this function with new constraints. Passing in null for the and should cancel the temporal constraint and return the adapter to standard / real-time operation.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

member.summary: Gets the flag that determines if measurements sent to this are destined for archival.
member.remarks: This property allows the to calculate statistics on how many measurements have been archived per minute. Historians would normally set this property to true; other custom exports would set this property to false.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.SupportsTemporalProcessing
member.summary: Gets the flag indicating if this implementation supports temporal processing.
member.remarks: For output adapters that archive data it is assumed that the desired behavior will be to not support temporal processing since the data being processed has already been archived (i.e., no need to attempt to rearchive old data). As a result the default behavior for an output adapter is to not support temporal processing when is true. If you have an output adapter that you want to support temporal data processing independent of the value, then override this property and force the base value to the desired state.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.ProcessingInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired processing interval, in milliseconds, for the output adapter.
member.remarks: With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, this value specifies the desired processing interval for data, i.e., basically a delay, or timer interval, over which to process data. A value of -1 means to use the default processing interval while a value of 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

member.summary: Gets flag that determines if the data output stream connects asynchronously.

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.RemoveMeasurements(System.Int32)
member.summary: This removes a range of measurements from the internal measurement queue.
member.remarks: This method is typically only used to curtail size of measurement queue if it's getting too large. If more points are requested than there are points available - all points in the queue will be removed.

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.Flush
member.summary: Blocks the current thread, if the is connected, until all items in queue are processed, and then stops processing.

remarks.para: It is possible for items to be added to the queue while the flush is executing. The flush will continue to process items as quickly as possible until the queue is empty. Unless the user stops queuing items to be processed, the flush call may never return (not a happy situation on shutdown).
The does not clear queue prior to destruction. If the user fails to call this method before the class is destructed, there may be items that remain unprocessed in the queue.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Alarm.SetPoint
member.summary: Gets or sets the value to be compared against the signal to determine whether to raise the alarm. This value is irrelevant for the operation.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Alarm.Tolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets a tolerance window around the to use when comparing against the value of the signal. This value is only relevant for the and operations.

remarks.para: The equal and not equal operations are actually internal and external range tests based on the setpoint and the tolerance. The two tests are performed as follows.

list.item: Not equal: (value < SetPoint - Tolerance) || (value > SetPoint + Tolerance)

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Alarm.Delay
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of time that the signal must be exhibiting alarming behavior before the alarm is raised.

member.summary: Gets or sets the hysteresis used when clearing alarms. This value is only relevant in greater than (or equal) and less than (or equal) operations.

remarks.para: The hysteresis is an offset that provides padding between the point at which the alarm is raised and the point at which the alarm is cleared. For example, in the case of the operation:

member.name: T:GSF.TimeSeries.ConcentratorBase
member.summary: Measurement concentrator base class.

remarks.para: This class synchronizes (i.e., sorts by timestamp) real-time measurements.

Note that your lag time should be defined as it relates to the rate at which data is coming into the concentrator. Make sure you allow enough time for transmission of data over the network allowing any needed time for possible network congestion. Lead time should be defined as your confidence in the accuracy of your local clock (e.g., if you set lead time to 2, this means you trust that your local clock is within plus or minus 2 seconds of real-time.)

This concentrator is designed to sort measurements being transmitted in real-time for data being sent at rates of at least 1 sample per second. Slower rates (e.g., once every few seconds) are not supported since sorting data at these speeds would be trivial. There is no defined maximum number of supported samples per second - but keep in mind that CPU utilization will increase as the measurement volume and frame rate increase.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.ConcentratorBase.ProcessingInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired processing interval, in milliseconds, for the adapter.

remarks.para: This property is normally only used when you need the concentrator to send data at faster than real-time speeds, e.g., faster than the defined . A use case would be pushing historical data through the concentrator where you want to sort and publish data as quickly as possible.

With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, this value specifies the desired processing interval for data, e.g., a timer interval, over which to process data. A value of -1 means to use the default processing interval, i.e., use the , while a value of 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

From a real-time perspective the defines its general processing interval based on the defined property. The frames per second property, however, is more than a basic processing interval since it is used to define the intervals in one second that will become the time sorting destination "buckets" used by the concentrator irrespective of the data rate of the incoming data. As an example, if the frames per second of the concentrator is set to 30 and the source data rate is 60fps, then data will be down-sampled to 30 frames of sorted incoming data but the assigned processing interval will be used to publish the frames at the specified rate.

The implemented functionality of the process interval property will be to respond to values in the following way:
Value Response
< 0
In this case the default processing interval has been requested, as a result the will be set to false and the concentrator processing interval will be defined based on the currently defined property, e.g., if the frames per second is 30 the processing interval will be 33.33ms.
0
In this case the processing interval has been defined to process data as fast as possible, as a result the property will be set to true and property will be set to false. With a processing interval of zero data is expected to flow into the concentrator as quick as it can be provided. The property will still be used to sort data by time into appropriate frames, but the concentrator will use the reception time of the measurements against the defined lag-time to make sure needed data has arrived before publication and frames will be published at the same rate of data arrival.
> 0
In this case a specific processing interval has been defined for processing data, as a result both the and properties will be set to true. With a specifically defined processing interval, data is expected to flow into the concentrator at a similar rate. The property will still be used to sort data by time into appropriate frames, but the concentrator will use the reception time of the measurements against the defined lag-time to make sure needed data has arrived before publication and frames will be published on the specified interval. If multiple frames are ready for publication when the processing interval executes, then all the ready frames will be published sequentially as quickly as possible.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.ConcentratorBase.MaximumPublicationTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum frame publication timeout in milliseconds, set to (-1) to wait indefinitely.

remarks.para: The concentrator automatically defines a precision timer to provide the heartbeat for frame publication, however if the system gets busy the heartbeat signals can be missed. This property defines a maximum wait timeout before reception of the heartbeat signal to make sure frame publications continue to occur in a timely fashion even when a system is under stress.

This property is automatically defined as 2% more than the number of milliseconds per frame when the property is set. Users can override this default value to provide custom behavior for this timeout.

member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if timestamp reasonability checks should be performed on incoming measurements (i.e., measurement timestamps are compared to system clock for reasonability using tolerance).
member.remarks: Setting this value to false will make the concentrator use the latest value received as "real-time" without validation; this is not recommended in production since time reported by source devices may be grossly incorrect. For non-production configurations, setting this value to false will allow concentration of historical data.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.ConcentratorBase.ProcessByReceivedTimestamp
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if concentrator should sort measurements by received time.

remarks.para: Setting this value to true will make concentrator use the timestamp of measurement reception, which is typically the creation time, for sorting and publication. This is useful in scenarios where the concentrator will be receiving very large volumes of data but not necessarily in real-time, such as, reading values from a file where you want data to be sorted and processed as fast as possible.
Setting this value to true will force to be true and to be false.

member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if system should track timestamp of publication for all frames and measurements.
member.remarks: Setting this value to true will cause the concentrator to mark the timestamp of publication in each and its measurement's . Since this is extra processing time that may not be needed except in cases of calculating statistics for system performance, this must be explicitly enabled.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.ConcentratorBase.AllowSortsByArrival
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines whether or not to allow incoming measurements with bad timestamps to be sorted by arrival time.

remarks.para: Value defaults to true, so any incoming measurement with a bad timestamp quality will be sorted according to its arrival time. Setting the property to false will cause all measurements with a bad timestamp quality to be discarded. This property will only be considered when is false.
Value will be forced to false if is true.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.ConcentratorBase.UseLocalClockAsRealTime
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines whether or not to use the local clock time as real-time.

remarks.para: Use your local system clock as real-time only if the time is locally GPS-synchronized, or if the measurement values being sorted were not measured relative to a GPS-synchronized clock.
If is true, will always be set to true, even if you try to set it to false.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.ConcentratorBase.RealTime
member.summary: Gets the most accurate time value that is available. If = true, then this function will return . Otherwise, this function will return the timestamp of the most recent measurement, or if no measurement timestamps are within time deviation tolerances as specified by the value.
member.remarks: Because the measurements being received by remote devices are often measured relative to GPS time, these timestamps are typically more accurate than the local clock. As a result, we can use the latest received timestamp as the best local time measurement we have (ignoring transmission delays); but, even these times can be incorrect so we still have to apply reasonability checks to these times. To do this, we use the local system time and the value to validate the latest measured timestamp. If the newest received measurement timestamp gets too old or creeps too far into the future (both validated + and - against defined lead time property value), we will fall back on local system time. Note that this creates a dependency on a fairly accurate local clock - the smaller the lead time deviation tolerance, the better the needed local clock accuracy. For example, a lead time deviation tolerance of a few seconds might only require keeping the local clock synchronized to an NTP time source; but, a sub-second tolerance would require that the local clock be very close to GPS time.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.ImmediateMeasurements.LeadTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed future time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be sub-second).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to future measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too advanced.

member.exception: LeadTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.summary: Updates the statistics for the number of measurements received and the number of measurements expected in the wrapped by this helper.
member.remarks: Call this periodically, preferably on a slow timer (e.g., once per second), in order to update the and statistics.

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.Statistics.DeviceStatisticsHelper`1.Update(System.Int64)
member.summary: Updates the statistics for the number of measurements received and the number of measurements expected in the wrapped by this helper.
member.param: The current time, in ticks.
member.remarks: Call this periodically, preferably on a slow timer (e.g., once per second), in order to update the and statistics. This method is preferred when tracking statistics for multiple s to reduce the number of calls to .

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.Statistics.DeviceStatisticsHelper`1.Reset
member.summary: Resets the member variables used to track statistics for the device wrapped by this helper.
member.remarks: Call this when the connection to a device has been reset to mark a starting point for statistics gathering. Since the method keeps track of the time it was last called, it is necessary to call this method during long periods of downtime where Update was not being called in order to avoid momentary, unexpectedly large values to be calculated for measurements expected.

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.Statistics.StatisticsEngine.RegexMatch(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the given signal reference matches the signal reference regular expression using the given suffix.
member.param: The signal reference to be matched against the regular expression.
The suffix used by a particular type of statistic.
member.returns: Flag indicating whether the signal reference matches the regular expression.
member.remarks: The format for signal reference of statistics is: ACRONYM!SUFFIX-ST#, where ACRONYM is the acronym of the measurement's source, SUFFIX is the suffix given as a parameter to this method, and # is an index used to differentiate between statistics with the same source and type.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.ClientConnection.HasClientNotFoundExceptionOccurred
member.summary: Gets/Sets a flag to indicate that the error "No client found for ID [Guid]" exception has been thrown.
member.returns:
Since this message might be thrown many times before before the communication channel has a chance to disconnect the socket, it's best to stop attempting to send data when this error has been encountered.
OGE has had issues when a client disconnects, tens of thousands of exceptions get thrown (every 3ms), This has caused the entire system to become unresponsive and causes all PMUs to drop offline. System only recovers when the client disconnect process finally executes as this can take some time to occur.

member.name: T:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.ServerCommand
member.summary: Server commands received by and sent by .
member.remarks: Solicited server commands will receive a or response code along with an associated success or failure message. Message type for successful responses will be based on server command - for example, server response for a successful MetaDataRefresh command will return a serialized of the available server metadata. Message type for failed responses will always be a string of text representing the error message.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.ServerCommand.Authenticate
member.summary: Authenticate command.
member.remarks: Requests that server authenticate client with the following encrypted authentication packet. Successful return message type will be string indicating client ID was validated. Client should not attempt further steps if authentication fails, user will need to take action. Client should send MetaDataRefresh and Subscribe commands upon successful authentication. If server is setup to not require authentication, authentication step can be skipped - however it will be up to the implementation to know if authentication is required - the server cannot be queried to determine if authentication is required. It is expected that use of this protocol between gateways over a shared network (i.e., the lower security zone) will require authentication. It is expected that use of this protocol between gateway and other systems (e.g., a PDC) in a private network (i.e., the higher security zone) can be setup to not require authentication.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.ServerCommand.MetaDataRefresh
member.summary: Meta data refresh command.
member.remarks: Requests that server send an updated set of metadata so client can refresh its point list. Successful return message type will be a containing server device and measurement metadata. Received device list should be defined as children of the "parent" server device connection similar to the way PMUs are defined as children of a parent PDC device connection. Devices and measurements contain unique Guids that should be used to key metadata updates in local repository. Optional string based message can follow command that should represent client requested meta-data filtering expressions, e.g.: "FILTER MeasurementDetail WHERE SignalType <> 'STAT'"

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.ServerCommand.Subscribe
member.summary: Subscribe command.
member.remarks: Requests a subscription of streaming data from server based on connection string that follows. It will not be necessary to stop an existing subscription before requesting a new one. Successful return message type will be string indicating total number of allowed points. Client should wait for UpdateSignalIndexCache and UpdateBaseTime response codes before attempting to parse data when using the compact measurement format.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.ServerCommand.Unsubscribe
member.summary: Unsubscribe command.
member.remarks: Requests that server stop sending streaming data to the client and cancel the current subscription.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.ServerCommand.RotateCipherKeys
member.summary: Rotate cipher keys.
member.remarks: Manually requests that server send a new set of cipher keys for data packet encryption.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.ServerCommand.UpdateProcessingInterval
member.summary: Update processing interval.
member.remarks: Manually requests server to update the processing interval with the following specified value.

member.summary: Define operational modes for subscriber connection.
member.remarks: As soon as connection is established, requests that server set operational modes that affect how the subscriber and publisher will communicate.

member.name: T:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataPacketFlags
member.summary: data packet flags.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataPacketFlags.Synchronized
member.summary: Determines if data packet is synchronized.
member.remarks: Bit set = synchronized, bit clear = unsynchronized.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataPacketFlags.Compact
member.summary: Determines if serialized measurement is compact.
member.remarks: Bit set = compact, bit clear = full fidelity.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataPacketFlags.CipherIndex
member.summary: Determines which cipher index to use when encrypting data packet.
member.remarks: Bit set = use odd cipher index (i.e., 1), bit clear = use even cipher index (i.e., 0).

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataPacketFlags.Compressed
member.summary: Determines if data packet payload is compressed.
member.remarks: Bit set = payload compressed, bit clear = payload normal.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataPacketFlags.LittleEndianCompression
member.summary: Determines if the compressed data payload is in little-endian order.
member.remarks: Bit set = little-endian order compression, bit clear = big-endian order compression.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataPacketFlags.NoFlags
member.summary: No flags set.
member.remarks: This would represent unsynchronized, full fidelity measurement data packets.

member.name: T:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes
member.summary: Operational modes that affect how and communicate.
member.remarks: Operational modes are sent from a subscriber to a publisher to request operational behaviors for the connection, as a result the operation modes must be sent before any other command. The publisher may silently refuse some requests (e.g., compression) based on its configuration. Operational modes only apply to fundamental protocol control.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes.VersionMask
member.summary: Mask to get version number of protocol.
member.remarks: Version number is currently set to 0.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes.CompressionModeMask
member.summary: Mask to get mode of compression.
member.remarks: GZip and TSSC compression are the only modes currently supported. Remaining bits are reserved for future compression modes.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes.EncodingMask
member.summary: Mask to get character encoding used when exchanging messages between publisher and subscriber.
member.remarks:
00 = UTF-16, little endian
01 = UTF-16, big endian
10 = UTF-8
11 = ANSI

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes.UseCommonSerializationFormat
member.summary: Determines type of serialization to use when exchanging signal index cache and metadata.
member.remarks: Bit set = common serialization format, bit clear = .NET serialization format. The .NET serialization format is only for backwards compatibility with older GEP implementations and considered obsolete, it may be removed from future builds.

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes.ReceiveExternalMetadata
member.summary: Determines whether external measurements are exchanged during metadata synchronization.
member.remarks: Bit set = external measurements are exchanged, bit clear = no external measurements are exchanged

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes.ReceiveInternalMetadata
member.summary: Determines whether internal measurements are exchanged during metadata synchronization.
member.remarks: Bit set = internal measurements are exchanged, bit clear = no internal measurements are exchanged

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes.CompressPayloadData
member.summary: Determines whether payload data is compressed when exchanging between publisher and subscriber.
member.remarks: Bit set = compress, bit clear = no compression

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes.CompressSignalIndexCache
member.summary: Determines whether the signal index cache is compressed when exchanging between publisher and subscriber.
member.remarks: Bit set = compress, bit clear = no compression

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes.CompressMetadata
member.summary: Determines whether metadata is compressed when exchanging between publisher and subscriber.
member.remarks: Bit set = compress, bit clear = no compression

member.name: F:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.OperationalModes.NoFlags
member.summary: No flags set.
member.remarks: This would represent protocol version 0, UTF-16 little endian character encoding, .NET serialization and no compression.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataGapRecoverer.RecoveryStartDelay
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum time delay, in seconds, to wait before starting the data recovery for an .

remarks.para: For some archiving systems it may take a few seconds for data to make it to disk and therefore be readily available for a temporal subscription query. The should be adjusted based on the nature of the system used to archive data. If the archival system makes data immediately available because of internal caching or other means, this value can be zero.

Use of this value depends on the local clock, as such the value should be increased by the uncertainty of accuracy of the local clock. For example, if it is know that the local clock floats +/-5 seconds from real-time, then increase the desired value of the by 5 seconds.

member.exception: Value cannot be a negative number.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataGapRecoverer.DataMonitoringInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the interval, in seconds, over which the data monitor will check for new data.
member.remarks:
Once a connection is established a timer is enabled to monitor for new incoming data. The data monitoring timer exists to make sure data is being received so that the process of recovery does not wait endlessly for data that may never come because of a possible error in the recovery process. The allows the consumer to adjust the interval over which the timer will check for new incoming data.
It will take some time, perhaps a couple of seconds, to start the temporal subscription and begin the process of recovering data for an . Make sure the value for is sufficiently large enough to handle any initial delays in data transmission.
member.exception: Value cannot be zero or a negative number.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataGapRecoverer.MinimumRecoverySpan
member.summary: Gets to sets the minimum time span, in seconds, for which a data recovery will be attempted. Set to zero for no minimum.
member.exception: Value cannot be a negative number.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataGapRecoverer.MaximumRecoverySpan
member.summary: Gets to sets the maximum time span, in seconds, for which a data recovery will be attempted. Set to for no maximum.
member.exception: Value cannot be zero or a negative number.

member.remarks: Leave value blank for default path, i.e., installation folder. Can be a fully qualified path or a path that is relative to the installation folder, e.g., a value of "ConfigurationCache" might resolve to "C:\Program Files\MyTimeSeriespPp\ConfigurationCache\".

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataGapRecoverer.FilterExpression
member.summary: Gets or sets the filter expression used to define which measurements are being requested for data recovery during an .

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataGapRecoverer.RecoveryProcessingInterval
member.summary:
Gets or sets the data recovery processing interval, in whole milliseconds, to use in the temporal data subscription when recovering data for an .
A value of -1 indicates the default processing interval will be requested.
A value of 0 indicates data will be processed as fast as possible.
member.remarks: With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, the value specifies the desired historical data playback processing interval in milliseconds. This is basically a delay, or timer interval, over which to process data. Setting this value to -1 means to use the default processing interval while setting the value to 0 means to process data as fast as possible, i.e., as fast as the historian can query the data. Depending on the available bandwidth, this parameter may need to be adjusted such that the data being recovered does not adversely interfere with the ongoing transmission of real-time data.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataGapRecoverer.UseMillisecondResolution
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag that determines whether measurement timestamps use millisecond resolution. If false, time will be of resolution.
member.remarks: If the source and destination historians can handle timestamps at a greater than millisecond resolution then the can be set to false to ensure that a full resolution timestamp is delivered through the data recovery process. Setting this property to true allows the temporal subscription used in the data recovery process to conserve data transmission bandwidth since not as much space will be needed for a timestamp with only millisecond resolution.

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataGapRecoverer.FlushLog(System.Int32)
member.summary: Blocks calling thread until data gap has been flushed to disk.
member.param: Optional time-out for waiting thread block. Defaults to waiting indefinitely.

remarks.para: Data gap log is automatically persisted to disk as items are added or removed from the log. This function only exists to force a flush and block calling thread until flush has completed.

Function first waits for any pending data gap operation to complete then waits for data gap log to be flushed. Both waits use the same value, as a result it is possible that total wait time could be longer than specified wait time.

member.returns: true if log was flushed successfully; otherwise, false if flush timed out.

remarks.para: When the or temporal processing constraints are defined (i.e., not null), this specifies the start and stop time over which the subscriber session will process data. Passing in null for the and specifies the subscriber session will process data in standard, i.e., real-time, operation.

With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, the value specifies the desired historical playback data processing interval in milliseconds. This is basically a delay, or timer interval, over which to process data. Setting this value to -1 means to use the default processing interval while setting the value to 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

Passing in null for the and specifies the subscriber session will process data in standard, i.e., real-time, operation.

With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, the value specifies the desired historical playback data processing interval in milliseconds. This is basically a delay, or timer interval, over which to process data. Setting this value to -1 means to use the default processing interval while setting the value to 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats:
Time Format Format Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033 Absolute date and time.
* Evaluates to .
*-20s Evaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10m Evaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1h Evaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1d Evaluates to 1 day before .

member.summary: Defines extension functions related to .

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.CompactMeasurementExtensions.CompressPayload(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.CompactMeasurement},GSF.IO.BlockAllocatedMemoryStream,System.Byte,System.Boolean,GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.DataPacketFlags@)
member.summary: Attempts to compress payload of values onto the stream.
member.param: Payload of values.
Memory based stream to hold compressed payload.
Compression strength to use.
Flag that determines if time should be included in the compressed payload.
Current .
member.returns: true if payload was compressed and encoded onto stream; otherwise false.

remarks.para: Compressed payload will only be encoded onto stream if compressed size would be smaller than normal serialized size.

As an optimization this function uses a compression method that uses pointers to native structures, as such the endian order encoding of the compressed data will always be in the native-endian order of the operating system. This will be an important consideration when writing a endian order neutral payload decompressor. To help with this the actual endian order used during compression is marked in the data flags. However, measurements values are consistently encoded in big-endian order prior to buffer compression.

member.name: T:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.SignalIndexCache
member.summary: Represents a serializable signal ID to index cross reference.
member.remarks: This class is used to create a runtime index to be used for data exchange so that a 16-bit integer is exchanged in the data packets for signal identification instead of the 128-bit Guid signal ID to reduce bandwidth required for signal exchange. This means the total number of unique signal IDs that could be exchanged using this method in a single session is 65,535. This number seems reasonable for the currently envisioned use cases, however, multiple sessions each with their own runtime signal index cache could be established if this is a limitation for a given data set.

Frame rate of the subscription in frames per second.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.SynchronizedSubscriptionInfo.RemotelySynchronized
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag that determines whether this subscription is remotely synchronized or locally synchronized.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.SynchronizedSubscriptionInfo.FramesPerSecond
member.summary: Gets or sets the frame rate of the subscription in frames per second.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.SynchronizedSubscriptionInfo.DownsamplingMethod
member.summary: Gets or sets the down-sampling method used when the frame rate of the subscription is lower than the frame rate of the measurement's source.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.SynchronizedSubscriptionInfo.AllowPreemptivePublishing
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag that determines whether frames should be published as soon as the data is available. If false, frames will be published when their timestamp expires (realTime > timestamp + lagTime).

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.SynchronizedSubscriptionInfo.AllowSortsByArrival
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag that determines whether to allow measurement sorting based on the measurement's time of arrival, if its timestamp is unreasonable.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.SynchronizedSubscriptionInfo.IgnoreBadTimestamps
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag that determines whether to ignore bad timestamps when sorting measurements.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.SynchronizedSubscriptionInfo.TimeResolution
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum time resolution, in ticks, to use when sorting measurements by timestamps into their proper destination frame.
member.remarks:
Desired maximum resolution Value to assign
Seconds .
Milliseconds .
Microseconds .
100-Nanoseconds 0
Assigning values less than zero will be set to zero since minimum possible concentrator resolution is one tick (100-nanoseconds). Assigning values values greater than . will be set to . since maximum possible concentrator resolution is one second (i.e., 1 frame per second).

member.summary: Gets or sets the desired processing interval, in milliseconds, for the adapter.
member.remarks: With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, this value specifies the desired processing interval for data, i.e., basically a delay, or timer interval, over which to process data. A value of -1 means to use the default processing interval while a value of 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.Transport.SynchronizedClientSubscription.SupportsTemporalProcessing
member.summary: Gets the flag indicating if this adapter supports temporal processing.
member.remarks: Although this adapter provisions support for temporal processing by proxying historical data to a remote sink, the adapter does not need to be automatically engaged within an actual temporal , therefore this method returns false to make sure the adapter doesn't get automatically instantiated within a temporal session.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.TemporalMeasurement.LagTime
member.summary: Allowed past time deviation tolerance in seconds (can be sub-second).

remarks.para: This value defines the time sensitivity to past measurement timestamps.
Defined the number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too old.

member.exception: LagTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: P:GSF.TimeSeries.TemporalMeasurement.LeadTime
member.summary: Allowed future time deviation tolerance in seconds (can be sub-second).

remarks.para: This value defines the time sensitivity to future measurement timestamps.
Defined the number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too advanced.

member.exception: LeadTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.TemporalMeasurement.GetAdjustedValue(GSF.Ticks)
member.summary: Gets numeric adjusted value of this , constrained within specified ticks.

remarks.para: Operation will return NaN if ticks are outside of time deviation tolerances.
Note that returned value will be offset by adder and multiplier.

member.param: Timestamp used to constrain (typically set to real-time, i.e. "now").
member.returns: Value offset by adder and multiplier (i.e., Value * Multiplier + Adder).

member.name: M:GSF.TimeSeries.TemporalMeasurement.GetValue(GSF.Ticks)
member.summary: Gets numeric value of this , constrained within specified ticks.

remarks.para: Operation will return NaN if ticks are outside of time deviation tolerances.

member.param: Timestamp, in ticks, used to constrain (typically set to real-time, i.e. "now").
member.returns: Raw value of this measurement (i.e., value that is not offset by adder and multiplier).
